awd_titl_txt: Development of Ultrashort Relativistic Electron Beams as a Plasma Diagnostic
awd_abstract_narration:
A very powerful laser can be used to accelerate electrons to high energies by interacting with a state of matter known as a plasma, an ionized gas of charged particles. The laser achieves this by creating waves in the plasma, like a boat pushing through water, on which the electrons can surf and be accelerated to high energies.  In this project, electrons accelerated with lasers will be used to image and, in turn, better understand the behavior of the plasma itself.  The techniques and understanding obtained in this study will further help the development of compact particle accelerators, which can impact everything from cancer therapy to imaging stresses in aircraft wings. 

Electron beams produced by laser driven plasma waves are especially brief in duration and tightly focused, so they may be used for imaging of very rapidly changing phenomena. In this project, one of the most powerful lasers in the world, the NSF funded HERCULES laser at the University of Michigan, will be used to create electron beams to probe electromagnetic field structures that are produced when lasers interact with solid materials. In particular, these include surface magnetic fields, reconnecting magnetic fields and Weibel instability filaments. An intense electron beam will also be used to heat and produce high energy density plasmas which can be used to better understand astrophysically relevant phenomena in a laboratory setting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A very powerful laser can be used to accelerate electrons to high energies by interacting with a state of matter known as a plasma, an ionized gas of charged particles. The laser achieves this by creating waves in the plasma, like a boat pushing through water, on which the electrons can surf and be accelerated to high energies. In this project, electrons were accelerated using some of the most powerful lasers, which produce such plasma waves. We understood better how the production of these electrons occurred by developing new diagnostics of the coupling of energy from the plasma and understanding the electron positions and energies in the plasma wave.

The electron beams we produced using laser-driven plasma-waves are especially brief in duration and tightly focused, so they may be used for imaging of very rapidly changing phenomena and understand the physics of the field dynamics. For example, by scaling the results to a laboratory setting, we may better understand astrophysically relevant phenomena such as magnetic field dynamics. In this project, some of the most powerful lasers in the world were used to create strong surface magnetic fields by heating solid targets. By using two laser pulses, two magnetic field structures were generated, which could be brought into proximity by strong heat flows, which redirected the magnetic field energy. We modeled how electron beams could probe the electromagnetic field structures that are produced when lasers interact with plasma. When the laser is extremely intense, using an electron beam probe can act as a seed for charged particle cascades. We used electron beams to generate electron beam filaments through an electromagnetic instability that is similar those found in extreme astrophysical events such as galactic jets.

The graduate students involved in the project received intensive “hands-on” training in plasma diagnostic techniques in experiments using a world-class high-power laser system. By running advanced particle-in-cell kinetic plasma simulations, the students are being educated in the fundamental underlying processes of laser-plasma interactions. These skills are not only valuable for academic careers, but are also highly sought after by industry, for example semiconductor device manufacturers developing new XUV sources. The techniques and understanding obtained in this study will also help the development of compact particle accelerators, which themselves can impact everything from cancer therapy to imaging stresses in aircraft wings.
